Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YHK-MT71-JBSN-1005-00000-00Election Special: Antitrust on the Ballot2020-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:07ZLexisNexisElection Special: Antitrust on the Ballotby David Hatch

As former Vice President Joe Biden solidifies his lead for the Democratic presidential nomination, Gene Kimmelman, a prominent Washington voice on antitrust, is dreaming big.

The Obama-era Department of Justice enforcer and longtime gadly on the perils of consolidation is quietly floating a new competition authority to tackle the disruptive forces reshaping markets.

This nimble twenty-first century digital DNA agency would target specific elements of the internet economy preventing competition from developing, Kimmelman told The Deal.

Standing alongside the DOJ and Federal Trade Commission as Washington s newest regulatory cop, it would dismantle barriers to entry in online search, advertising and commerce.

Kimmelman s bold vision likely requires the political equivalent of a royal flush a Democratic sweep of the White House and Congress and support from the business community and regulators to stand a chance.

Even then, it s certain to trigger pushback from corporations and Big Government critics worried about overreach, making it an apt metaphor for the stakes on antitrust in the 2020 election.

Competition policy is too arcane to rival healthcare or abortion as a signature campaign topic, but it bubbled to the surface as https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/20001871/index.dl|debate fodder in October as Sens. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) railed against Big Tech.

Warren, who dropped out in March, laid down the gauntlet a year earlier with a provocative plan to https://medium.com/@teamwarren/heres-how-we-can-break-up-big-tech-9ad9e0da324c|break up Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL), Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) and Facebook, Inc. (FB).

Sanders followed in October with a corporate accountability https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/20001845/index.dl|blueprint that emphasized splitting apart monopolies and railed against concentration in sectors from agribusiness to eyewear.

With Biden, a moderate, on track for the nomination, fears of a Teddy Roosevelt-style trustbusting zeitgeist marking an end to megamergers have faded.

But Warren and Sanders could still influence the Democratic party platform and a new administration, and a Biden presidency would have ample opportunity to shake up merger analysis.

Changes Under Biden

While a President Biden might not share the draconian views espoused by progressives, he could still give executives ulcers.

An ongoing Democratic-led congressional investigation of the market power of leading tech giants might resonate deeply with the former Delaware senator, who would face enormous pressure to act on upcoming https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/14996805/index.dl|recommendations that could include dismantling digital platforms.

If a Biden administration were coupled with Democratic control of Congress, lawmakers might be motivated to update antitrust statutes to make it easier to challenge mergers.

That could mean more attempts to block vertical transactions that combine complementary assets and increased leverage to halt or unwind killer acquisitions designed to eliminate emerging rivals.

The FTC s two Democrats have repeatedly https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/14875426/index.dl|criticized the commission as lax on enforcement of vertical tie-ups that rarely face challenges, enunciating their objections with no votes and scathing dissents.

Tech behemoths under investigation in Washington probably would prefer a second Trump term to a President Sanders, Sally Hubbard, director of enforcement strategy at the anti-monopoly Open Markets Institute, told The Deal.

Yet they might actually fare better under Biden, she observed. As a businessperson, I would prefer predictability, added Hubbard, who previously served as assistant attorney general in the New York state antitrust bureau.

Kimmelman was at the DOJ in 2011 when the agency cleared Comcast s $30 billion takeover of NBCUniversal Inc. with extensive behavioral restrictions. He expects more use of this tool under Democratic control.

You ll see a broader array of remedies viewed as acceptable in a Democratic administration, he said.

Trump s enforcers have favored structural fixes, but there are notable exceptions.

Behavioral conditions imposed on the nearly complete acquisition of Sprint Corp. (S) by T-Mobile USA Inc. (TMUS) helped stave off a legal challenge, and the FTC required behavioral fixes for the office supply marriage of Staples Inc. and Essendant Inc. (ESND).

Checks and Balances

Regardless of their trustbuster pronouncements on the stump, candidates face political realities once in office.

What we don t know is what the change in demeanor is from the campaign trail and the rhetoric to the actual governing process, noted Kimmelman, senior adviser to Public Knowledge, a digital rights organization active on merger issues.

The judiciary, Congress, corporations, trade associations, advocacy groups and other stakeholders all hold sway.

Whichever party wins, they ultimately have to go before the courts and prove their case, Kimmelman emphasized. The judiciary must sign off on DOJ consent decrees and can torpedo legal challenges to mergers.

If enforcers reach beyond the limits of existing antitrust law, they re just going to get shot down, he warned, adding that over the past forty years, courts have made it more difficult for prosecutors to prevail.

Federal courts twice cleared AT&T s purchase of Time Warner over DOJ objections and greenlighted T-Mobile-Sprint despite resistance from state attorneys general.

One judge s opinion can determine a lot, Hubbard said.

Kimmelman also argued that congressional control is as important as taking the White House.

I don t think that Sen. Sanders or Sen. Warren can accomplish much of what they re asking for without amending the antitrust laws, he cautioned.

Adding more presumptions in the law about anticompetitive behavior based on market concentration or business practices could make it easier for the government to win legal challenges, he said.

For such legislation to stand a chance, however, a Democratic House and Senate is almost certainly required.

Still, Hubbard suggested that a Democratic president could recalibrate some aspects of existing law even without congressional intervention.

A more aggressive enforcement stance could help evolve the law in the right direction by displacing legal precedent that makes it difficult to bring monopolization cases and other challenges, she explained.

Another variable is congressional oversight. It s usually more pronounced when led by the opposition, but friction can exist when it's conducted by the same party.

The main way presidents exert influence over competition policy is through the selection of nominees who share their priorities.

They could do a lot just by having the right people in charge at the FTC and the DOJ, Hubbard said of the Democrats.

That alone, without changing any case law or passing any legislation, would make a very big difference, she added, citing recent FTC merger clearances under razor-thin 3-2 margins.

A more aggressive DOJ antitrust division chief might be more willing to challenge the sorts of sizable horizontal transactions greenlighted by Trump s point man, Makan Delrahim, with conditions, Hubbard noted.

With Delrahim reportedly looking to exit, Trump might have the opportunity to appoint a second-term replacement. The DOJ didn t respond to a request for comment.

Of course, nominees can veer from White House priorities. Unless you have a president who is willing to just fire people who don t do exactly what he wants, enforcers can make independent judgments, Kimmelman said.

Compared with Biden, a Sanders administration would be more likely to push the limits of antitrust by taking bigger risks on litigation and interpretation of statutes and case law, both antitrust specialists agreed.

The Vermont senator also could be expected to work with a Democratic-controlled Congress to require leading digital platforms to be regulated as public utilities, a goal shared by Warren.

Even if Sanders follows Warren in dropping out, both could impact the party platform or apply pressure by joining a Biden administration. Warren already is being floated for vice president or a Cabinet post such as Treasury Secretary.

Populist Themes

It would ve been tempting to expect sharp contrasts on antitrust between a second Trump term and a President Sanders, but in some respects, they're aligned.

While Sanders is more strident in his criticism, both have criticized large corporations as part of their populist messages.

The current administration could conclude its tech investigations with enforcement actions that dovetail with Democratic threats, such as unraveling mergers or suing over anticompetitive behavior.

In October, Sanders vowed that his FTC would thoroughly review all mergers since Trump became president and undo those that have created highly concentrated markets, demonstrably caused harm to workers, raised prices, or reduced competition.

He'd also task the commission with evaluating all deals over the past 40 years to establish new guidelines that factor economic and job security into merger analysis.

In a related move, Trump's FTC https://pipeline.thedeal.com/article/20003929/index.dl|announced in February it would analyze hundreds of smaller, nonreportable acquisitions by five leading Silicon Valley titans over the past decade. Purchases deemed anticompetitive could be unwound.

As Democrats demand stepped-up enforcement of vertical mergers, it was the Trump administration that tried to block the acquisition of Time Warner by AT&T Inc. (T), marking the DOJ s first litigated challenge of a complementary combination in more than four decades.

While some skeptics think the department sued to appease Trump's disdain for Time Warner s CNN, allegations the antitrust division denies, the fact remains that Republicans took this bold step.

As the Trump administration faces accusations of political interference on AT&T and other transactions, Sanders and Warren may have opened themselves to accusations they prejudged which companies should be dismantled.

But Hubbard insisted that the progressives are on solid ground.

There s plenty of analysis out there, she said, including academic research, hearings and her own writings on the dominance of tech giants. I don t think you can really call it bias when it s based on evidence and research.

Kimmelman is a senior fellow at the Shorenstein Center s digital platforms & democracy project, part of Harvard s Kennedy School, where he honed his vision of a new competition authority.

It s loosely modeled after a similar proposal developed for the U.K. government by a panel headed by Jason Furman, chief economic adviser to former President Barack Obama.

For now, Kimmelman s concept is encapsulated in a https://protect-eu.mimecast.com/s/CSqbCK1mmimP6BGIM_8Zq?domain=shorensteincenter.org|scholarly paper quietly posted to the center s website, patiently waiting for political stars to align.

DEAL SIZE

$ 50 Billion and Up

urn:contentItem:5XFS-HP71-DXP9-93SY-00000-00Electoral arithmetic causes pain in Spain2019-11-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:07ZLexisNexisElectoral arithmetic causes pain in SpainMehreen Khan in Brussels

FT subscribers can click here to receive Brussels Briefing every day by email.Spanish voters head to the ballot box for the fourth time in f... FT subscribers can click here to receive Brussels Briefing every day by email. Spanish voters head to the ballot box for the fourth time in four years on Sunday but few are...

FT subscribers can click here to receive Brussels Briefing every day by email.Spanish voters head to the ballot box for the fourth time in f... FT subscribers can click here to receive Brussels Briefing every day by email. Spanish voters head to the ballot box for the fourth time in four years on Sunday but few are...

FT subscribers can click here to receive Brussels Briefing every day by email.Spanish voters head to the ballot box for the fourth time in f...

FT subscribers can click here to receive Brussels Briefing every day by email.

Spanish voters head to the ballot box for the fourth time in four years on Sunday but few are expecting this weekend’s vote to unlock the country's political deadlock.

Latest polls show Pedro Sánchez’s ruling Socialists will emerge as the largest party but with a diminished standing that will leave the prime minister in much the same position he’s been in for the last year: scrambling around for coalition allies.

This telling graphic from Kiko Llaneras for El País shows how loose loyalties among the electorate will make for an unpredictable election and complicate the coalition arithmetic for Mr Sánchez and his conservative rivals.

The chart above shows voting intentions this weekend compared to last April’s general election.

While a bulk of supporters (over 60 per cent) say they will stick with Mr Sánchez’s PSOE or the centre-right PP, the highest voter fealty is for the resurgent far-right Vox party (over 85 per cent). Vox is expected to near double its vote share to around 14 per cent according to the polls. Undecided voters could also prove pivotal. A healthy chunk of former Sánchez voters say they are now unsure who to back.

As the FT Big Read explains, it is the Catalan issue and the politics of secession that has blown apart Spain’s political landscape. Vox has taken an unequivocally anti-secessionist line on Catalonia — gazumping other conservative forces like the PP and the liberal Ciudadanos who have used the crisis to rail against Mr Sánchez’s leadership.

Vox’s momentum is causing nervousness among the country’s elites. An open letter signed by 500 academics and researchers on Thursday accuses the party of using falsified and manipulated academic studies to claim migration is linked to rising crime.

Miguel Otero-Iglesias, senior analyst at the Elcano Royal Institute, thinks Sunday’s vote will again deliver a parliament that has no clear majority on either left or right.

“Spain has a split political system and for now leaders struggle to come together and form coalitions,” says Mr Otero-Iglesias.

Mr Sánchez has options but most are laden with risk and potentially unstable. He could strike a deal with the centre-right PP that would allow the Socialists to rule as a minority government with the tacit support of the conservatives, who would demand concessions on key issues. Mr Sánchez’s main alternative is to try and repair strained relations with the anti-establishment Podemos after failing to convince them to agree a coalition deal and triggering this weekend's election. But even a Podemos alliance could leave him short of a majority.

Mr Otero-Iglesias thinks it was a “disaster” for Ciudadanos to rule out an alliance with the Socialists in April — a move that has provoked soul searching in the party and helped lead to Friday’s paralysis. “It was a missed opportunity to have a combination of social policies and pro-business structural reforms”, he says. That opportunity looks to have come and gone.

Chart du jour: hitting the brakes

The European Commission has trimmed its eurozone GDP forecast to the lowest since 2015 this year and warned no bounceback is on the horizon. Trade tumult, a global manufacturing slowdown, and the prospect of a bad Brexit are all reasons for the “protracted” euro gloom. (FT)

Planet Europe

Macron waxes lyrical
Emmanuel Macron has won praise from the Kremlin with some headline-grabbing comments declaring the “brain death” of Nato in an interview with The Economist. The diatribe has opened up another rift between Paris and Berlin (Ms Merkel has said the “drastic” proclamation is “not my view”). Here’s Mr Macron in full:

“To my mind, what we are currently experiencing is the brain death of NATO. We have to be lucid . . . You have partners together in the same part of the world, and you have no co-ordination whatsoever of strategic decision-making between the United States and its Nato allies. None. You have an uncoordinated aggressive action by another Nato ally, Turkey, in an area where our interests are at stake.”

François Heisbourg thinks Mr Macron is talking like a “policy-detached think-tanker”. The president has also angered Bosnians by claiming the country is a ticking “time bomb” threatened by returning jihadis from Syria.   Sarajevo has summoned the French ambassador to explain the remarks.   Here's the Macron transcript in full. (Klix, Economist)

Breton’s business
France’s EU commission nominee has promised to “automatically recuse” himself of all financial links to his former Atos software company in an eight-page declaration to the European Parliament. Mr Breton however stayed silent on potential regulatory conflicts of interest in his new job. He could have his formal MEP hearing as early as next week. ( Politico)

Banking disunion
Italy’s finance minister Roberto Gualtieri has rebuffed a German plan to complete the banking union as leading to an “unlevel” playing field in Europe. Mário Centeno, eurogroup chief, on Thursday night however hailed a “new mood” on breaking a deadlock that has persisted for over seven years. ( FT)

30 years on
Carnegie Europe‘s Judy Dempsey has gathered an array of academics and journalists to mark the 30 year anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.

Tightening up on tech
Ursula von der Leyen wants Europe to “shape our own approach to the digital world” — remarks that suggest her commission won’t shy away from regulating Big Tech. Even more tellingly, the president-elect made the comments at a speech celebrating the famed author of The Age of Surveillance Capitalism. ( here’s the FT’s review) Adding to platforms’ worries, EU transparency commissioner Vera Jourova on Thursday at the Lisbon Web Summit warned social media giants could face new rules curbing their powers on illegal content and the transparency of political ads.

Farage cries foul, and wins
EU judges have ruled Nigel Farage’s Eurosceptic parliamentary alliance was unfairly treated by the parliament over demands to repay EU funding. ( The Guardian)

Coming up today
EU finance ministers are expected to end a long running saga over how to apply tax duties to home-made alcohol with an exemption limited at 50 litres per year. Bottoms up!

;  @mehreenkhn

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VC0-8WH1-F03R-N4B2-00000-00Electoral Reform Society urges reform of 'wild west' political campaigning online2019-02-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:07ZLexisNexisElectoral Reform Society urges reform of 'wild west' political campaigning onlineKeumarsA

Feb 05, 2019( IT Pro: http://www.itpro.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) A coalition of politicians, campaigners and public interest groups have warned that elections in the UK are at risk of interference because campaign laws have not kept up with the emerging digital infrastructure. The growing use of social media platforms and services managed by big tech companies also poses a risk to democracy given these spaces are widely unregulated, according to a report published by the Electoral Reform Society (ERS). The 60-page report, titled 'Reining in the Political Wild West: Campaigning Rules for the 21st Century[1]', was published yesterday to coincide with the Facebook's 15th anniversary. In it, a range of voices have argued the firm and its rivals like Google and Twitter must be more transparent on how campaign groups use their platforms, and how personal data is used to spread information. "With talk of a fresh general election or referendum heating up, the need to bring Britain's outdated election laws into the 21st century is urgent," said the ERS' director of research and policy Dr Jess Garland.

"Make no mistake: our democracy is under threat from dark ads, dodgy donations and disinformation, but with the right rules online campaigning can be a real force for good. The government should listen to these vital proposals and take action before it's too late." She warned that Facebook, among other social media giants, has changed how campaigning works, yet online political campaigning "remains an unregulated Wild West". The next election, moreover, sees a real risk of "foreign interference and dodgy dealings" without urgent action.The 'one missing piece' in legislationPolitical parties spent around 1.3 million on Facebook during the 2015 general election, a figure that almost doubled during the 2017 campaign to 3.2 million, with data-driven campaigning spawning an entire industry.The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO)[2] suggests the one missing piece in legislation, now that the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)[3] has come into force, is a statutory code of practice. "We're waiting for a response from government to that recommendation, but we feel as though this should be a statutory code in the same way as we have a code of practice on data protection in the media," said the ICO's deputy commissioner for policy Steve Wood. "We also feel that this will set out a level playing field for all of the different actors who are using data for political purposes, about what they can do with data. "It shouldn't create a chilling effect: it should enable parties to understand how they can use digital campaigning techniques, because we're not as a regulator saying, 'you can't use digital campaigning tools', but it's about how you use them safely and transparently in accordance with the law." The report also set out a series of recommendations for policymakers and social media companies which should, in theory, reduce the risk of any interference in political campaigning as well as the prevalence of disinformation. One effective short-term measure, according to the report, would involve extending the requirement for online advertising to be 'imprinted'; where all materials must show who produced and funded them. Creating a universal and publicly-available online database of political adverts, which would also be searchable, could also raise transparency and allow voters to identify the origins of a post or message.Advertising to an audience of oneAmong meatier recommendations include additional enforcement powers for organisations like the Electoral Commission, to match the ICO's considerably-increased powers since GDPR came into force. The ERS also echoed the ICO in suggesting political parties must work with the government to establish a legally-binding code of practice, while policymakers must urgently reform electoral law to future-proof political regulations for a digital landscape. Emerging threats to democracy may include incorporating technologies like deep learning[4] into micro-targeting, according to Demos' senior researcher with the centre for analysis of social media (CASM) Josh Smith. "As voter profiles become increasingly detailed, use of this technology by campaigns could lead to their targeting people based on characteristics, such as health, race or sexual preference, which campaign organisers may not be aware they are using," he said. "This could be true even where protected characteristics are not stored, as machine learning makes it possible to infer detailed demographic information based on seemingly innocuous data." "Political groups may soon be able to incorporate data gleaned from 'wearables' the Internet of Things (IoT)[5] into their messaging, or to algorithmically generate entirely new slogans and designs." "The direction of travel is towards campaigns being able to address each voter individually, based on their specific profile; advertising to an audience of one. This individual targeting risks breaking down public political discourse - having a conversation about what a party stands for in the run-up to a campaign is difficult if your neighbours and family have seen completely different messages." The report has been published in light of three major public investigations into the relationship between tech giants and political campaign groups, with activity during the 2016 EU Referendum, particularly under the spotlight. Both the Electoral Commission and ICO have reprimanded the pro-Brexit group Leave.EU[6]for overspending, and the misuse of data[7] respectively, in tandem with probing social media companies like Facebook and Google. Meanwhile, Parliament's Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DMCS) select committee has led an ongoing investigation into the phenomenon of disinformation and fake news, which itself has recommended that government introduce tighter regulations for tech companies[8]. [ 1]: https://www.electoral-reform.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/Reining-in-the-Political-Wild-West-Campaign-Rules-for-the-21st-Century.pdf [ 2]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/information-commissioner/31751/what-is-the-information-commissioner-s-office-ico [ 3]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/it-legislation/27814/what-is-gdpr-everything-you-need-to-know [ 4]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/neural-network/30250/what-is-deep-learning [ 5]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/cloud-computing/28037/what-is-iot [ 6]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/policy-legislation/31594/tech-giants-like-facebook-should-be-made-liable-for-fake-news-dcms [ 7]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/data-insights/32900/ico-fines-leaveeu-and-arron-banks-insurance-120000-over-marketing-law-breaches [ 8]:   https://www.itpro.co.uk/policy-legislation/31594/tech-giants-like-facebook-should-be-made-liable-for-fake-news-dcms

Creating a universal and publicly-available online database of political adverts, which would also be searchable, could also raise transparency and allow voters to identify the origins of a post or message.

Advertising to an audience of one

Among meatier recommendations include additional enforcement powers for organisations like the Electoral Commission, to match the ICO's considerably-increased powers since GDPR came into force.

The ERS also echoed the ICO in suggesting political parties must work with the government to establish a legally-binding code of practice, while policymakers must urgently reform electoral law to future-proof political regulations for a digital landscape.

Emerging threats to democracy may include incorporating technologies like deep learning into micro-targeting, according to Demos' senior researcher with the centre for analysis of social media (CASM) Josh Smith.

"As voter profiles become increasingly detailed, use of this technology by campaigns could lead to their targeting people based on characteristics, such as health, race or sexual preference, which campaign organisers may not be aware they are using," he said.

"This could be true even where protected characteristics are not stored, as machine learning makes it possible to infer detailed demographic information based on seemingly innocuous data."

"Political groups may soon be able to incorporate data gleaned from 'wearables' the Internet of Things (IoT) into their messaging, or to algorithmically generate entirely new slogans and designs."

"The direction of travel is towards campaigns being able to address each voter individually, based on their specific profile; advertising to an audience of one. This individual targeting risks breaking down public political discourse - having a conversation about what a party stands for in the run-up to a campaign is difficult if your neighbours and family have seen

completely different messages."

The report has been published in light of three major public investigations into the relationship between tech giants and political campaign groups, with activity during the 2016 EU Referendum, particularly under the spotlight.

Both the Electoral Commission and ICO have reprimanded the pro-Brexit group Leave.EU for overspending, and the   misuse of data respectively, in tandem with probing social media companies like Facebook and Google.

Meanwhile, Parliament's Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DMCS) select committee has led an ongoing investigation into the phenomenon of disinformation and fake news, which itself has recommended that government introduce tighter regulations for tech companies.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6103-2Y71-JB13-7010-00000-00Electric Shock to New Entrants2020-09-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:07ZLexisNexisECONOMYNew Energy VehiclesElectric Shock to New EntrantsXu Dawei and Su Jiede

As local authorities jumped on the new energy vehicle bandwagon, many found that lack of regulation and low barriers to entry are seeing a greater drive towards bankruptcy than profits.

Once a shining light in the electric vehicle (EV) industry in Jiangsu Province, JiangsuSaleen Automotive Technology (JSAT) has suspended all production. In early June, two of JSAT's factories in the city of Rugao, Jiangsu Province, were seized by the local intermediate court, its bank account was locked and virtually all its employees resigned, placing the city's once burgeoning EV industry in limbo.

JSAT spent nearly 6 billion yuan (US$86m) on factories, employees, marketing and manufacturing, but only 31 low-end electric cars were ever sold. In the opinion of Wang Xiaolin, chairman of JSAT, the money was far from enough to make a car. "Among all EV manufacturers in China, JSAT is the most cost-effective. We have rich experience in financial control. An electric vehicle will never be produced without an investment of 10 billion yuan (US$1.4b)," he told China Report in the US.

According to Qiao Yudong, former senior legal manager at JSAT, Rugao had a public budget of 7 billion yuan (US$100m) in 2019, most of which was sunk into JSAT's EV project. On April 27, Qiao reported Wang Xiaolin as being "a false technology investor who has embezzled a huge amount of State assets."

Chen Jianjun, deputy director of Rugao government's publicity department, told China Report that the failure of the JSAT project has become a salutary lesson for other cities in Jiangsu and government agencies. "We should be more careful when we launch EV projects in the future and more stringent examination is needed to check the qualifications of enterprises."

China started boosting new energy vehicle (NEV) strategies in 2009, when it began offering support measures, which included nationwide subsidies. Government data shows that from 2015 to 2017, more than 200 NEV projects were launched in the Chinese mainland with a total investment of 1 trillion yuan (US$143b) and accumulated manufacturing capacity of over 21.24 million vehicles.

In 2019, Chinese automobile sales started to decline across the board, and government subsidies have decreased also. There are now 40 new energy vehicle manufacturers in China. Yet local governments are still enthusiastic over the prospect of investing in the NEV industry.

"The automobile industry is so attractive to local governments because it can drive the development of an entire industrial chain," said Li Jinyong, deputy director of China Auto Dealers Chamber of Commerce. "It's the biggest source of tax revenue."

Car-building Mania Rugao has a population of 14.2 million people and it has become well-known in Jiangsu Province as a new energy vehicle city. In the wake of the 2008 economic crisis, the city's industrial base, which included international shipping, photovoltaic production and biological medicine, was floundering. Rugao cast its eyes at the developing NEV industry and released a package of measures to lure investment. Chen Xiaodong, Party chief of the city, said publicly that NEV manufacturing was a strategic decision.

Established in 2009, Rugao New Energy Auto Industrial Park occupies an area of 20 square kilometres with a dozen NEV manufacturers, including JSAT and GreenWheel EV. There are also more than 30 enterprises involved in the supply chain, including lithium battery makers, tires and auto parts.

The industrial park aimed to produce 800,000 vehicles with an output value of 100 billion yuan (US$14.35b) by the end of 2020, becoming China's most competitive NEV industrial base for auto manufacturing, trade, finance, culture and service in the Yangtze River Economic Belt.

In 2010, Rugao introduced its first new energy vehicle enterprise " GreenWheel EV, with a planned investment of 4 billion yuan (US$574m) and an annual production capacity of 200,000 EVs. The company back then did not have a manufacturing licence for EVs, and it was only after intervention from the Rugao government that the firm obtained permission to produce mid-size and large electric buses.

In 2012, the provincial economic and information commission designated Rugao as the only NEV industrial base in Jiangsu Province. But the high cost of attracting auto manufacturing enterprises also generated high risks for the local government. Auto enterprises based in the industrial park have fallen one by one because of financial shortfalls, technical difficulties or poor sales.

In early 2020, GreenWheel EV halted production. According to a report released by Pingan Bank in June 2020, GreenWheel EV owed the bank 112 million yuan (US$16m) and interest payments of 1.25 million yuan (US$180,000). The bank has transferred 24 percent of the company's equity and 280,000 square metres of industrial land to other companies.

Wang Xiaoxiang, adviser to the NEV industry in Rugao, said that local governments see the automobile industry as a lucrative sector that can drive employment. "Local governments want big projects. As long as one major project is inked and goes into production, GDP in the area will rise to a new level," he told China Report.

Cui Dongshu, secretary-general of the China Passenger Car Association, told China Report that the fundamental goal of any local government is to drive economic development and NEV projects have become the perfect engines. From 2015 to 2017, more than 20 NEV projects were inked in Zhejiang Province alone.

"An economic output of 20 billion yuan (US$2.9b) will be created if 100,000 vehicles with a single price of 200,000-yuan (US$28,700) could be sold," he said.

Land use rights are the ace in the hole for local governments to obtain investments from auto manufacturers. Rugao provided JSAT with 1.6 square kilometres of land. GreenWheel EV also obtained 0.8 square kilometres of land from the local government.

"Many EV manufacturers acquired land at a very low price, so even if they fail to make a single vehicle, they can still get a lot of profit from selling on the land," Cui said.

Struggle to Survive Starting in 2020, an increasing number of EV manufacturers in China have declared or are on the verge of bankruptcy, including Bordrin, Byton and Qiantu, all based in Jiangsu, and SD EV based in Henan Province. Many NEV companies had starry launches with funds from big tech and management connected to prominent names in auto manufacturing, including foreign firms like BMW, or in the case of JSAT, Steve Saleen, a former racing driver and designer.

Li Jinyong, deputy director of the China Auto Dealers Chamber of Commerce, told our reporter that an industrial reshuffle in the sector is unavoidable. Generally speaking, NEV enterprises have a relatively small and weak industrial chain, but traditional auto enterprises have advantages in economies of scale which are based on an output of over 10 million vehicles.

"The production costs of NEV enterprises are still too high," Li said. "It would be nice if three or five NEV enterprises could survive."

Nowadays, NEV enterprises are no longer highly sought after in the capital market especially after a continued reduction in government subsidies. Zhang Wei, chairman of Co-Stone Capital, argued that no NEV enterprise in China is worthy of investment.

Whether NEV enterprises can survive or not largely depends on support from local governments, who have become the largest source of finance for the NEV sector. Auto industry analyst Zhong Shi told our reporter that NEV enterprises deliberately bind themselves with State assets and shoulder risks with local governments. If there is a problem, he said, it is very difficult for State assets to retreat.

In June, Nanjing Byton Electric Vehicle Corporation said it was experiencing a crisis which reportedly meant a four-month delay to salaries. In April, its office in Shanghai was closed and in June its office in Beijing shut. Its factory in Nanjing, capital of Jiangsu, closed because of arrears in utilities.

"We have invested billions of yuan into the Byton project. If it's declared bankrupt, it will be a great burden to repay the debt," an employee at the management committee of Nanjing Economic and Technology Development Zone said, on condition of anonymity.

Local governments mainly invest in land and factory buildings, so if a business fails, these means of production can be reused. Cui Dongshu said that it is the bank that suffers most. "The investment comes from banks, and there is a high likelihood it will become a bad asset," he said.

Several auto industry insiders told our reporter that it is difficult for local governments to appraise the technological credentials of NEV enterprises. To make matters worse, local governments lack awareness of risk control and most of the time studying the feasibility of a joint-venture project is a formality.

Jiangxi Province was criticised by the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) due to excessive investment in the NEV industry. From 2015 to 2017, Jiangxi introduced 18 NEV projects but some never even started production. Eleven did start, but seven are behind schedule.

Xia Yingjie, chairman of Jiangxi Jiangling Motors Overseas Sales Company and a member of Jiangxi Political Consultative Conference, warned that most NEV enterprises in the province have weak financial backing and R&D. It is high time to raise the entry threshold for NEV enterprises, Xia said, and their design capability, manufacturing quality and marketing capacity must be subject to strict oversight in order to avoid overcapacity in low-end products.

On January 10, 2019, the NDRC issued an investment regulation on the NEV industry which states that before a new project is launched, local governments should eliminate all zombie enterprises in the sector, and existing enterprises should accomplish the scheduled output. In addition, NEV enterprises should have core technologies in design, manufacturing and battery production. The NDRC also delegated the power of examination and approval of NEV projects to the provincial government.

Jia Xinguang, chief analyst at China Automobile Industry Consulting, argued that the delegation of power has pushed provincial governments to balance NEV development in accordance with the specific circumstances of different cities and their strengths.

"In previous years, local governments' attitude towards NEV projects was the more, the better. Nowadays, provincial governments tend to support one or two key projects," he said. "If a project fails, the NDRC is quite likely to end all NEV projects in the province."

urn:contentItem:60SY-T571-JCSC-J30J-00000-00Electric vehicle newbie Nikola soars while Tesla and Big Tech's sell-off worsens: CNBC After Hours2020-09-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:07ZLexisNexisNEWSElectric vehicle newbie Nikola soars while Tesla and Big Tech's sell-off worsens: CNBC After HoursArielle Berger

CNBC.com's MacKenzie Sigalos brings you the day's top business news headlines. On today's show, CNBC's Phil LeBeau breaks down the just-announced partnership between Nikola and General Motors. Plus, CNBC's Meg Tirrell explains why nine leading pharmaceutic... CNBC.com's MacKenzie Sigalos brings you the day's top business news headlines. On today's...

CNBC.com's MacKenzie Sigalos brings you the day's top business news headlines. On today's show, CNBC's Phil LeBeau breaks down the just-announced partnership between Nikola and General Motors. Plus, CNBC's Meg Tirrell explains why nine leading pharmaceutic...

CNBC.com's MacKenzie Sigalos brings you the day's top business news headlines. On today's show, CNBC's Phil LeBeau breaks down the just-announced partnership between Nikola and General Motors. Plus, CNBC's Meg Tirrell explains why nine leading pharmaceutical CEOs made a pledge to prioritize safety during Covid-19 vaccine development. Tesla shares crater more than 20% after S&P 500 snub Tesla shares tumbled Tuesday, after Elon Musk's electric vehicle maker was left out of the S&P 500 by the committee that decides on new additions to the index. Tesla shares were down more than 20% in afternoon trading. The stock has been on a tear this year, having risen around 400%, and the company is now worth more than some of the world's largest automakers, including Toyota and Volkswagen. On Friday, the S&P 500 Index Committee decided to add e-commerce site Etsy, automatic test equipment maker Teradyne and pharmaceutical firm Catalent to the S&P 500, but stopped short of including Tesla. Some investors had expected Tesla to be included this quarter, after it reported its fourth consecutive quarter of profitability in July. Nikola shares pop as much as 53% after General Motors takes 11% stake in electric truck maker Shares of Nikola surged Tuesday after General Motors announced it's taking an 11% stake in the electric truck maker and will produce its marquee hydrogen fuel cell electric pickup truck the Badger by the end of 2022. Shortly before the opening bell, Nikola shares were up 30% and GM's were 6% higher. Nikola shares had popped by as much as 53% while GM's jumped as much as 9.1% in the premarket trading. GM is getting a $2 billion stake in Nikola and the right to nominate one board member in exchange for in-kind services. Phoenix-based Nikola specializes in building zero-emission semi trucks using battery or hydrogen fuel cell technology, but it recently introduced its Badger pickup truck for consumers. This will also make GM the exclusive supplier of Nikola's fuel cells globally, except Europe, for its class 7/8 trucks. U.S., European drugmakers pledge to make safety the main focus in coronavirus vaccine development Nine leading U.S. and European vaccine developers pledged on Tuesday to uphold the scientific standards that their experimental immunizations will be held against, amid a hurried global race to contain the pandemic. The companies, including Pfizer, GlaxoSmithKline and AstraZeneca, in a joint statement made a "historic pledge... to uphold the integrity of the scientific process as they work towards potential global regulatory filings and approvals of the first Covid-19 vaccines." The unusual move to promise to play by well-established rules underlines a highly politicized debate over what action is needed to quickly rein in the spread of the deadly disease and to jumpstart global business and trade.

value.Title: Elevation Partners' Roger McNamee is Intvd on Blmbg TV

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KSD-7F71-DY0W-4341-00000-00Elevation Partners' Roger McNamee is Intvd on Blmbg TV2015-05-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:07ZLexisNexisElevation Partners' Roger McNamee is Intvd on Blmbg TVLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

MAY 14, 2015

SPEAKERS: ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS

PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Now they're called unicorns because once they were rare, well now not so much. They are private companies worth $1 billion or more, based on fundraising. And they include companies such as Uber, Airbnb and Fitbit. Well there are 25 unicorns this year, bringing the total to more than 100. Uber is perhaps the most well know, with an estimated $50 billion valuation.

So are all unicorns created equal? Roger McNamee is a successful veteran technology investor, and Co-Founder of Elevation Partners. And he joins me now to share his insights. Roger, thank you so much for being here.

ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS: Pimm, it's a great pleasure.

PIMM: Let's start off just talking about this idea of these billion-dollar or more private companies, but that's based on fundraising. That's not maybe real money, in some people's eyes. Tell me.

MCNAMEE: Well it's real money --

PIMM: Yes?

MCNAMEE: -- because they are -- people are writing checks --

PIMM: Okay.

MCNAMEE: -- based on getting whatever percentage of the company you get at those valuations. So clearly there is something going on here that we have never seen before. There have been private companies with billion-dollar valuations, Facebook was there. LinkedIn was there. Twitter was there. But now there are more than 100. And that is clearly without precedent.

And here's the good news. When -- at some level it is a speculative mania by venture capitalists, but the other side of the coin is every great industry in America was built on the back of a speculative mania, starting with the railroads in the 1830s and 1840s. And so to me the great thing about American culture it when we decide we like something, we just we throw out all the rules. We pretend like it really is different this time. And we put all this money into it.

And the good news is after the market corrects, or crashes or whatever comes later, you have this great new industry. And I do think that what's going on now is, from an American economic point of view, a really exciting thing. Now, personally, I look at it as an investor and I go, now hang on just a sec, this doesn't feel like the sort of thing that's going to go on without interruption. I think we are going to see a correction here. And when it comes it could be really brutal.

FOX: When someone comes to Roger McNamee and says, you know what? There is this company and we would love you to participate, --

MCNAMEE: Yes.

FOX: -- what are some of the things in the checklist that would make you say, yes, $1 billion, that makes sense?

MCNAMEE: Well the way I look at this is there are some that are easy. I look at Uber and I think to myself that notwithstanding the, shall we say, unusual personality of the CEO, the service is universally loved, and it has plowed through regulatory barriers and political barriers very, very easily. And I don't know what -- I don't know how to value Uber. $50 billion seems like a big number, but who knows? It could -- I can imagine a scenario where it's worth that much.

Within that list of 100, there are bound to be a few which we look back on and go, wow, where was the sock puppet, right? And some of these are not going to work out well. And but the way I look at it is I think on balance we're better off seeing investors get too excited, because at least we wind up with a new industry.

And so when they're coming to me now, I'm looking at them all and going, you know, I think I'm going to wait. And it's not because I don't think they're great companies. It's because my 33 years as an investor in technology tells me there will be a day when the good ones will be available in the public market at a lower valuation. It's just markets go up and they go down. And I don't know whether that's a year from now, two years from now or five years from now, but the opportunity will come along. Things don't grow to the sky usually.

FOX: Let me -- let me give you a name. All right let's talk Fitbit.

MCNAMEE: Well there you go. So Fitbit is a company that, if I understand the forecast properly, is going to do over $1 billion in revenue this year. And it has carved a position beneath Apple in the wellness market. And the problem with the product is that the data it gives you is not accurate. The good news of the product is the social experience is marvelous.

And people really do use it and they really do love it. Now how do you value a situation like that, because they're always going to have to be cheaper than Apple. And they're going to have to watch out for Apple coming down and essentially grabbing their price point. I'm personally a shareholder victim. I'd -- I'd like to see what they can do with it.

How is it going to turn out? I haven't a clue. And am I going to get a chance to own it cheaper? Well once it's public the answer is inevitably, because things are going to go up and down, but they may go up before they go down, and that would be better for me, but I don't know that that's what's going to happen.

FOX: Is there a unicorn out there that you don't want to play leapfrog with?

MCNAMEE: Well the funny thing is I don't see it today, but I'm sure the answer is yes. What's exciting now is that the technology of smartphones for the last six or seven years was about making phones themselves. Now it's about applying that technology to changing other sectors of the economy, and creating use cases where people get benefit or enjoyment from things they never had before.

Think about Uber, I mean what a transformation of transportation. And that wave is going to last 10, 15 years fundamentally. So some of these things are going to emerge and wind up not only in the S&P 500, but if they do a great job, maybe in the Dow that you really do get a few things that do break through. The chances that we're going to have 100 of them that all do that in lockstep I think round to zero.

FOX: AOL and Verizon, what do you think of the deal?

MCNAMEE: So I look at it, and I go if I'm Tim Armstrong this is a great outcome. I mean AOL, their best case from here was just to keep hammering away. From Verizon's point of view, there is an opportunity for them to get some technology mojo that they haven't had. I find it highly unlikely that they will get that, simply because they have been so successful in their core markets that culturally the notion that they're going to adopt "Huffington Post" style, TechCrunch-style culture at Verizon, I wouldn't count on it. Most big tech deals don't work out for the buyer, but it's a great day for the AOL shareholder and for the team there.

FOX: I want to thank you very much, Roger McNamee of Elevation Partners, much appreciated.

1140

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KRW-JXV1-DY0W-417N-00000-00Elevation Partners' Roger McNamee is Intvd on Blmbg TV2015-05-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:07ZLexisNexisElevation Partners' Roger McNamee is Intvd on Blmbg TVLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

MAY 14, 2015

SPEAKERS: ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS

PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Now they're called unicorns because once they were rare, well now not so much. They are private companies worth $1 billion or more, based on fundraising. And they include companies such as Uber, Airbnb and Fitbit. Well there are 25 unicorns this year, bringing the total to more than 100. Uber is perhaps the most well know, with an estimated $50 billion valuation.

So are all unicorns created equal? Roger McNamee is a successful veteran technology investor, and Co-Founder of Elevation Partners. And he joins me now to share his insights. Roger, thank you so much for being here.

ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS: Pimm, it's a great pleasure.

PIMM: Let's start off just talking about this idea of these billion-dollar or more private companies, but that's based on fundraising. That's not maybe real money, in some people's eyes. Tell me.

MCNAMEE: Well it's real money --

PIMM: Yes?

MCNAMEE: -- because they are -- people are writing checks --

PIMM: Okay.

MCNAMEE: -- based on getting whatever percentage of the company you get at those valuations. So clearly there is something going on here that we have never seen before. There have been private companies with billion-dollar valuations, Facebook was there. LinkedIn was there. Twitter was there. But now there are more than 100. And that is clearly without precedent.

And here's the good news. When -- at some level it is a speculative mania by venture capitalists, but the other side of the coin is every great industry in America was built on the back of a speculative mania, starting with the railroads in the 1830s and 1840s. And so to me the great thing about American culture it when we decide we like something, we just we throw out all the rules. We pretend like it really is different this time. And we put all this money into it.

And the good news is after the market corrects, or crashes or whatever comes later, you have this great new industry. And I do think that what's going on now is, from an American economic point of view, a really exciting thing. Now, personally, I look at it as an investor and I go, now hang on just a sec, this doesn't feel like the sort of thing that's going to go on without interruption. I think we are going to see a correction here. And when it comes it could be really brutal.

FOX: When someone comes to Roger McNamee and says, you know what? There is this company and we would love you to participate, --

MCNAMEE: Yes.

FOX: -- what are some of the things in the checklist that would make you say, yes, $1 billion, that makes sense?

MCNAMEE: Well the way I look at this is there are some that are easy. I look at Uber and I think to myself that notwithstanding the, shall we say, unusual personality of the CEO, the service is universally loved, and it has plowed through regulatory barriers and political barriers very, very easily. And I don't know what -- I don't know how to value Uber. $50 billion seems like a big number, but who knows? It could -- I can imagine a scenario where it's worth that much.

Within that list of 100, there are bound to be a few which we look back on and go, wow, where was the sock puppet, right? And some of these are not going to work out well. And but the way I look at it is I think on balance we're better off seeing investors get too excited, because at least we wind up with a new industry.

And so when they're coming to me now, I'm looking at them all and going, you know, I think I'm going to wait. And it's not because I don't think they're great companies. It's because my 33 years as an investor in technology tells me there will be a day when the good ones will be available in the public market at a lower valuation. It's just markets go up and they go down. And I don't know whether that's a year from now, two years from now or five years from now, but the opportunity will come along. Things don't grow to the sky usually.

FOX: Let me -- let me give you a name. All right let's talk Fitbit.

MCNAMEE: Well there you go. So Fitbit is a company that, if I understand the forecast properly, is going to do over $1 billion in revenue this year. And it has carved a position beneath Apple in the wellness market. And the problem with the product is that the data it gives you is not accurate. The good news of the product is the social experience is marvelous.

And people really do use it and they really do love it. Now how do you value a situation like that, because they're always going to have to be cheaper than Apple. And they're going to have to watch out for Apple coming down and essentially grabbing their price point. I'm personally a shareholder victim. I'd -- I'd like to see what they can do with it.

How is it going to turn out? I haven't a clue. And am I going to get a chance to own it cheaper? Well once it's public the answer is inevitably, because things are going to go up and down, but they may go up before they go down, and that would be better for me, but I don't know that that's what's going to happen.

FOX: Is there a unicorn out there that you don't want to play leapfrog with?

MCNAMEE: Well the funny thing is I don't see it today, but I'm sure the answer is yes. What's exciting now is that the technology of smartphones for the last six or seven years was about making phones themselves. Now it's about applying that technology to changing other sectors of the economy, and creating use cases where people get benefit or enjoyment from things they never had before.

Think about Uber, I mean what a transformation of transportation. And that wave is going to last 10, 15 years fundamentally. So some of these things are going to emerge and wind up not only in the S&P 500, but if they do a great job, maybe in the Dow that you really do get a few things that do break through. The chances that we're going to have 100 of them that all do that in lockstep I think round to zero.

FOX: AOL and Verizon, what do you think of the deal?

MCNAMEE: So I look at it, and I go if I'm Tim Armstrong this is a great outcome. I mean AOL, their best case from here was just to keep hammering away. From Verizon's point of view, there is an opportunity for them to get some technology mojo that they haven't had. I find it highly unlikely that they will get that, simply because they have been so successful in their core markets that culturally the notion that they're going to adopt "Huffington Post" style, TechCrunch-style culture at Verizon, I wouldn't count on it. Most big tech deals don't work out for the buyer, but it's a great day for the AOL shareholder and for the team there.

FOX: I want to thank you very much, Roger McNamee of Elevation Partners, much appreciated.

1140

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

The chances that we're going to have 100 of them that all do that in lockstep I think round to zero.

FOX: AOL and Verizon, what do you think of the deal?

MCNAMEE: So I look at it, and I go if I'm Tim Armstrong this is a great outcome. I mean AOL, their best case from here was just to keep hammering away. From Verizon's point of view, there is an opportunity for them to get some technology mojo that they haven't had. I find it highly unlikely that they will get that, simply because they have been so successful in their core markets that culturally the notion that they're going to adopt "Huffington Post" style, TechCrunch-style culture at Verizon, I wouldn't count on it. Most big tech deals don't work out for the buyer, but it's a great day for the AOL shareholder and for the team there.

FOX: I want to thank you very much, Roger McNamee of Elevation Partners, much appreciated.

1140

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5G0H-6K61-F190-V0SD-00000-00Elevation Partners' Roger McNamee is Intvd on Blmbg TV2015-05-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:07ZLexisNexisElevation Partners' Roger McNamee is Intvd on Blmbg TV

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

MAY 14, 2015

SPEAKERS: ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS

PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Now they're called unicorns because once they were rare, well now not so much. They are private companies worth $1 billion or more, based on fundraising. And they include companies such as Uber, Airbnb and Fitbit. Well there are 25 unicorns this year, bringing the total to more than 100. Uber is perhaps the most well know, with an estimated $50 billion valuation.

So are all unicorns created equal? Roger McNamee is a successful veteran technology investor, and Co-Founder of Elevation Partners. And he joins me now to share his insights. Roger, thank you so much for being here.

ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS: Pimm, it's a great pleasure.

PIMM: Let's start off just talking about this idea of these billion-dollar or more private companies, but that's based on fundraising. That's not maybe real money, in some people's eyes. Tell me.

MCNAMEE: Well it's real money --

PIMM: Yes?

MCNAMEE: -- because they are -- people are writing checks --

PIMM: Okay.

MCNAMEE: -- based on getting whatever percentage of the company you get at those valuations. So clearly there is something going on here that we have never seen before. There have been private companies with billion-dollar valuations, Facebook was there. LinkedIn was there. Twitter was there. But now there are more than 100. And that is clearly without precedent.

And here's the good news. When -- at some level it is a speculative mania by venture capitalists, but the other side of the coin is every great industry in America was built on the back of a speculative mania, starting with the railroads in the 1830s and 1840s. And so to me the great thing about American culture it when we decide we like something, we just we throw out all the rules. We pretend like it really is different this time. And we put all this money into it.

And the good news is after the market corrects, or crashes or whatever comes later, you have this great new industry. And I do think that what's going on now is, from an American economic point of view, a really exciting thing. Now, personally, I look at it as an investor and I go, now hang on just a sec, this doesn't feel like the sort of thing that's going to go on without interruption. I think we are going to see a correction here. And when it comes it could be really brutal.

FOX: When someone comes to Roger McNamee and says, you know what? There is this company and we would love you to participate, --

MCNAMEE: Yes.

FOX: -- what are some of the things in the checklist that would make you say, yes, $1 billion, that makes sense?

MCNAMEE: Well the way I look at this is there are some that are easy. I look at Uber and I think to myself that notwithstanding the, shall we say, unusual personality of the CEO, the service is universally loved, and it has plowed through regulatory barriers and political barriers very, very easily. And I don't know what -- I don't know how to value Uber. $50 billion seems like a big number, but who knows? It could -- I can imagine a scenario where it's worth that much.

Within that list of 100, there are bound to be a few which we look back on and go, wow, where was the sock puppet, right? And some of these are not going to work out well. And but the way I look at it is I think on balance we're better off seeing investors get too excited, because at least we wind up with a new industry.

And so when they're coming to me now, I'm looking at them all and going, you know, I think I'm going to wait. And it's not because I don't think they're great companies. It's because my 33 years as an investor in technology tells me there will be a day when the good ones will be available in the public market at a lower valuation. It's just markets go up and they go down. And I don't know whether that's a year from now, two years from now or five years from now, but the opportunity will come along. Things don't grow to the sky usually.

FOX: Let me -- let me give you a name. All right let's talk Fitbit.

MCNAMEE: Well there you go. So Fitbit is a company that, if I understand the forecast properly, is going to do over $1 billion in revenue this year. And it has carved a position beneath Apple in the wellness market. And the problem with the product is that the data it gives you is not accurate. The good news of the product is the social experience is marvelous.

And people really do use it and they really do love it. Now how do you value a situation like that, because they're always going to have to be cheaper than Apple. And they're going to have to watch out for Apple coming down and essentially grabbing their price point. I'm personally a shareholder victim. I'd -- I'd like to see what they can do with it.

How is it going to turn out? I haven't a clue. And am I going to get a chance to own it cheaper? Well once it's public the answer is inevitably, because things are going to go up and down, but they may go up before they go down, and that would be better for me, but I don't know that that's what's going to happen.

FOX: Is there a unicorn out there that you don't want to play leapfrog with?

MCNAMEE: Well the funny thing is I don't see it today, but I'm sure the answer is yes. What's exciting now is that the technology of smartphones for the last six or seven years was about making phones themselves. Now it's about applying that technology to changing other sectors of the economy, and creating use cases where people get benefit or enjoyment from things they never had before.

Think about Uber, I mean what a transformation of transportation. And that wave is going to last 10, 15 years fundamentally. So some of these things are going to emerge and wind up not only in the S&P 500, but if they do a great job, maybe in the Dow that you really do get a few things that do break through. The chances that we're going to have 100 of them that all do that in lockstep I think round to zero.

FOX: AOL and Verizon, what do you think of the deal?

MCNAMEE: So I look at it, and I go if I'm Tim Armstrong this is a great outcome. I mean AOL, their best case from here was just to keep hammering away. From Verizon's point of view, there is an opportunity for them to get some technology mojo that they haven't had. I find it highly unlikely that they will get that, simply because they have been so successful in their core markets that culturally the notion that they're going to adopt "Huffington Post" style, TechCrunch-style culture at Verizon, I wouldn't count on it. Most big tech deals don't work out for the buyer, but it's a great day for the AOL shareholder and for the team there.

FOX: I want to thank you very much, Roger McNamee of Elevation Partners, much appreciated.

1140

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
